content.question: In pure water, some of the molecules ionize according to the equation <math alttext="H 2 O ionizes to produce H with a positive one charge, plus O H with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mo>⇄</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>OH</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </math>. The extent of the ionization increases with temperature. The graph above shows the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of pure water at different temperatures. Which of the following represents the variations in the <math alttext="p O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of pure water under the same conditions?

choices.label: The figure presents a graph that shows the p O H as a function of temperature. The horizontal axis is labeled Temperature, in degrees Celsius, and the numbers 0 through 90, in increments of 10, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled p O H, and the numbers 6.0 through 8.0, in increments of 0.4, are indicated. Eight data points are shown. The data represented in the graph are as follows. Note that all values are approximate. The data points begin at the Temperature, 10 degrees Celsius; p O H, 7.2, and trend almost linearly downward and to the right, ending at Temperature, 80 degrees Celsius; p O H, 6.3.

Note that all values are approximate. The data points begin at the Temperature, 10 degrees Celsius; p O H, 7.8, and trend almost linearly downward and to the right, to Temperature, 60 degrees Celsius; p O H, 7.0, and then horizontally and to the right to Temperature, 80 degrees Celsius; p O H, 7.0.
